questions.q: Let C(x) be 'computer x is connected to the network' and V(x, y) be 'computer x has a virus from computer y.' Which expression represents: 'There is a computer on the network that has not received a virus from any other computer'?
questions.explanation: ∃x means 'there is a computer', C(x) means 'on the network', and ∀y (¬V(x, y)) means 'not received a virus from any other computer y'.

questions.q: Let L(x, y) be 'x loves y.' What does the following statement mean? ∃x (L(x, Logic) ∧ ∀y ((y ≠ x) → ¬L(y, Logic)))
options: Everyone loves Logic except one person.
Someone loves Logic and Logic loves no one.
There is a person who loves only Logic.
questions.explanation: The first part says someone (x) loves Logic. The second part says if anyone else (y) is not x, they do not love Logic. This defines uniqueness.

questions.q: Express 'The sum of two positive integers is always positive' using quantifiers over the domain of Integers ℤ.
questions.explanation: This reads: 'For all x and all y, if x and y are positive, then their sum is positive.'

questions.q: Let P(x) be a predicate. Which statement is logically equivalent to ¬∃x ∀y (P(x) ∨ P(y))?
questions.explanation: Negating quantifiers flips them (∃ becomes ∀, ∀ becomes ∃) and De Morgan's Law changes (P ∨ Q) to (¬P ∧ ¬Q).

questions.q: Let W(x, y) mean person x works for company y. Translate: 'No one works for every company.'
questions.explanation: ¬∃x means 'there is no person x' such that they work for all y (∀y).

questions.q: Which rule of inference is used to derive the conclusion q ∨ r from the premises p ∨ q and ¬p ∨ r?
questions.explanation: Resolution takes two clauses with a literal and its negation to produce a new clause.

questions.q: Given the premises: ∀x(P(x) → Q(x)), P(c) for an arbitrary element c. What rule justifies the conclusion Q(c)?
options: Universal Instantiation followed by Modus Ponens
questions.explanation: First, you remove the 'for all' (Universal Instantiation) to get P(c) → Q(c), then apply Modus Ponens with P(c).

questions.q: What valid conclusion can be drawn from: (p ∧ q) → r and ¬r?
questions.explanation: By Modus Tollens, we get ¬(p ∧ q). By De Morgan's law, this is ¬p ∨ ¬q.

questions.q: Analyze the logical steps: 1. ∀x(P(x) → Q(x)), 2. ¬Q(a), 3. P(a) → Q(a) [Rule X], 4. ¬P(a) [Rule Y]. Identify Rule X and Rule Y.
options: X: Universal Generalization, Y: Modus Ponens
X: Universal Instantiation, Y: Modus Tollens
X: Existential Instantiation, Y: Modus Tollens
X: Universal Instantiation, Y: Disjunctive Syllogism
questions.explanation: X removes the quantifier for specific case 'a', and Y uses the negative conclusion to negate the premise.

questions.q: A detective reasons: 'If the butler committed the crime, then he was in the mansion at midnight. The butler was NOT in the mansion at midnight. Therefore, the butler did not commit the crime.' Which rule of inference is the detective using?
questions.explanation: If P then Q. Not Q. Therefore not P. This is Modus Tollens.

questions.q: To prove the statement 'For all integers n, if n² is odd, then n is odd' using Proof by Contraposition, what is the correct initial assumption?
options: Assume n is odd and n² is even
questions.explanation: Contraposition assumes the negation of the conclusion (n is not odd, so n is even) to prove the negation of the hypothesis.

questions.q: Identify the logical structure of the following proof attempt for the statement (P ∧ Q) → R: 'Suppose ¬R is true. We demonstrate that this implies ¬P ∨ ¬Q.'
questions.explanation: It assumes ¬Conclusion and derives ¬Hypothesis, which is the definition of contraposition.

questions.q: Determine the negation of the statement: 'There is a student in the class who has taken every course offered.'
options: Every student in the class has taken every course offered.
There is a student who has not taken any course offered.
For every student, there is a course they have not taken.
No student has taken any course.
questions.explanation: Negating 'Some student has taken all courses' becomes 'Every student has missed at least one course'.

questions.q: If C(x) means 'x is a car' and F(x) means 'x is fast', which symbolizes 'Only fast vehicles are cars'?
questions.explanation: 'Only A are B' translates to 'If B, then A'. Here, if it is a car, it must be fast.

questions.q: Let D(x) mean 'x is a doctor' and H(x) mean 'x works in a hospital'. What is the symbolic form of 'Not all doctors work in hospitals'?
questions.explanation: Option B (some doctor doesn't) and C (it's not true all do) are logically equivalent ways to say 'Not all'.

questions.q: If P(x) means 'x is a student' and Q(x) means 'x studies hard', what does ∃x(P(x) ∧ Q(x)) mean in English?
questions.explanation: ∃ means 'there exists' or 'some'.

questions.q: Let P(x,y) mean 'x is greater than y'. What is the meaning of ∀x∃y P(x,y)?
options: For every x, there is some y that is greater than x
For every x, there is some y that x is greater than
There exists an x that is greater than all y
There exists a y that is greater than all x
questions.explanation: It reads 'For all x, there exists a y such that x > y'.

questions.q: Let P(x) be 'x is a prime number' and Q(x) be 'x is odd.' Which statement represents 'All prime numbers except 2 are odd'?
questions.explanation: This specifies that if a number is prime and is not 2, then it must be odd.

questions.q: If P(x) is the statement 'x speaks French' and Q(x) is 'x knows Python', what is the logical equivalent of ¬∀x (P(x) → Q(x))?
options: Everyone speaks French and knows Python.
There is someone who speaks French but does not know Python.
There is someone who does not speak French and knows Python.
Everyone who knows Python does not speak French.
questions.explanation: The negation of 'All P are Q' is 'Some P are not Q'.

questions.q: Translating 'Unless you work hard (W), you will not succeed (¬S)' into logic results in:
questions.explanation: 'Unless P, Q' can be translated as 'If not P, then Q'. Here, if you don't work hard, you won't succeed.
